Title: Cortinarius sect. Armillati in North Europe
Keywords:
Agaricales, Barcoding, ITS, molecular systematics,
phylogeny, taxonomy
Abstract:
An extensive study of Cortinarius sect. Armillati
(subgenus Telamonia) was done based on morphology and molecular data. A
total of about 1000 specimens, mostly from Fennoscandia, were revised.
The nomenclature of the species was confirmed by sequencing the type
material. Phylogenetic relationships were inferred by analyses of ITS,
and the results were compared with the morphological and ecological
data. Based on macro- and micromorphological characters as well as
molecular data the sect. Armillati is limited to contain the medium- to
big-sized species with slightly hygrophanous pileus and Â± reddish or in
some species yellowish brown to rose brown universal veil. The other
red/brown-veiled species previously included in Armillati seem to belong
to at least seven different sections or clades: sect. Anthracini, sect.
Boulderenses, sect. Brunneotincti p.p., sect. Cinnabarini, sect.
Fulvescentes, /Fuscoperonatus, and /Praestigiosus. Based on our study
six Armillati species were recognized from North Europe: C. armillatus,
C. luteo-ornatus, C. paragaudis, and three species described as new C.
pinigaudis, C. roseoarmillatus, and C. suboenochelis. The former three
also occur in North America. In addition, two species outside the area,
C. subarmillatus (Japan) and C. quercoarmillatus (Costa Rica), are
known. Based on the phylogenetic analysis the species associated with
deciduous trees, C. armillatus, C. quercoarmillatus, and C.
roseoarmillatus all with dextrinoid, thick-walled spores, formed a
separate group from mainly conifer associated species, C. luteo-ornatus,
C. paragaudis, C. pinigaudis and C. suboenochelis all with fairly thin
to moderately thick-walled, indextrinoid to moderately dextrinoid
spores. Descriptions of the North European species are provided, the
distribution is mapped, and their taxonomy, ecology, distribution, and
relationships are discussed. A total of 64 new sequences of 12 species
are published including 17 sequences from type material. Our study also
suggests that ITS sequences are not always variable enough for species
level recognition (barcoding) in Cortinarius.
